purpose: To discuss the installation of CouchDB into devenv, builds, base images and peer images.
text: <@U1KJLGH8D|mariwade> set the channel purpose: To discuss the installation of CouchDB into devenv, builds, base images and peer images.
<@U11HH3P7Y> Can you please invite whoever else you feel should be invited to this slack channel.  Thank you
Instructions to manually install CouchDB into the vagrant dev environment.  <https://docs.google.com/document/d/1p0f7qLHe7V_LeRZRtMHQrYOXchHbwL4PtKWddET7tig/edit?usp=sharing>

I’ve included instructions to manually install CouchDB into the vagrant dev environment.  The next step is to update the .vagrantfile to automatically do this.   If anyone has any feedback please let me know.
Hi <@U1KJLGH8D> : Greg can you help you on this but right now he is super busy in release process..
I have checked in an initial changeset to automate the manual steps of installing couchDB into the devenv.   <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1865/>

<@U0KPFAZNF> - Where should the directory for couchDB source be? Outside (as in manual steps) or Inside (as in script) the hyperledger/fabric directory structure?   At this time we have not modified the source, and in that case the I felt the source should be pulled down outside the hyperledger/fabric directory so that the src was not included with git.  BUT there is a possibility that we may have some custom config and customizations which should be added to the git repository and in that case it should be included.  We may just need a temporary path until some development and architecture decisions are made. <@U0KPFAZNF> Greg, if you would please provide some input in the review.  Thank you.
i need to take a look to better understand before making a recommendation
ill try to do so this afternoon

hello ,everyone ,what is the meaning of the MVCC? the source is "runs validation logic (VSCC to check endorsement policy, and MVCC to check that ReadSet versions haven't changed in State DB since simulation time) "

<@U39S0S55F>  MVCC = Multi-version Concurrency Control.  Essentially at commit time there is validation logic that checks that the versions of keys that were read at simulation time have not been changed in the state database by other inflight transactions.  This ensures serializable isolation level, that is, no other inflight transactions have invalidated this transaction by changing inputs that were used during simulation.  The readset is part of the simulation results and travels with the writeset throughout the infrastructure.

Hi Dave <@U1KFCPFQA>. What happens if the validation fails at this stage? If the versions of keys have changed since the simulation for example. The transaction has already been endorsed, and submitted to the consensus service. Might some of the endorsing and committing peers have changed, and if so could some commit the change and some not? Or will they all be synchronised as they’re working off the same channel? Thanks :slightly_smiling_face:

the ordered transactions will be sent to all peers.  the validation check is deterministic and therefore all peers will come to the same conclusion of which trans are valid and not valid.  therefore the same set of validated trans will get applied to ledger on all peers.

Thanks Dave. So if validation fails because the version of keys has changed, the transaction is recorded in the ledger but flagged as ‘not valid’? Does the client which submitted the endorsed transaction to the consensus service receive notification of this?

By way of an example: Let’s say there is a simple chaincode that implements a basic bank account. It stores a balance, and allows debits and credits to the account. Debits are only allowed if the balance is greater than or equal to the amount being debited. 
The account balance starts with the value 100.
- Credit(50) (balance now 150).
- Debit(120) (balance now 30).

If there is a delay between the credit and debit, such that the credit is committed to the blockchain, then the debit will succeed. 
If the debit is invoked immediately after the credit without delay, then it will likely fail (as the balance is still 100 as the credit has not been committed). Similar to other non-blockchain systems.

Now, if we change the transactions to just 2 credits:
- Credit(50)
- Credit(20)

Similar to before, if there is a delay between to the credits, then they will succeed. But also, if the 2 transactions are submitted in quick succession, and are part of the same batch then the 2nd credit will fail validation as the first will change the key version?

A single client submitting these can synchronise these invocations, but it will be more difficult across multiple clients.

<@U1V6SJ1FF> You are absolutely correct.  If both credits happen at about the same time, then the post image from simulation will be 150 and 120 respectively.  At validation time, the first tran will succeed and change the ledger to 150, while the second tran will be marked invalid.  The client will get notified via an event, and can choose to re-submit.  The post image for the resubmission will be for the correct value of 170, and it will succeed during validation/commit phase, and all is good.  Note that for invalid transactions, they will be in the block but marked invalid, so that auditors can know what happened, but they will not be applied to the ledger state.

vp_1       | 2017-01-18 19:25:45.346 UTC [peer] Initialize -> INFO 069 Loading chain **TEST_CHAINID**
vp_1       | 2017-01-18 19:25:45.346 UTC [ledgermgmt] OpenLedger -> INFO 06a Opening leadger with id = **TEST_CHAINID**
vp_1       | create default chain [**TEST_CHAINID**] failed with Couch DB Error: Name: '**test_chainid**'. Only lowercase characters (a-z), digits (0-9), and any of the characters _, $, (, ), +, -, and / are allowed. Must begin with a letter.2017-01-18 19:25:45.346 UTC [couchdb] CreateCouchDatabase -> ERRO 06b Error during CouchDB CreateDatabaseIfNotExist() for dbName: **test_chainid**  error: Couch DB Error: Name: '**test_chainid**'. Only lowercase characters (a-z), digits (0-9), and any of the characters _, $, (, ), +, -, and / are allowed. Must begin with a letter.

it's not able to create the CouchDB with name `**test_chainid**`

Thanks <@U3U0MV3PZ>, this was an issue related to recent addition of multi-ledger support. Temporary fix is available in <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/4579/>, permanent fix will likely be delivered in the next week or two

Hello, Using Fabric v1.0 - For all the World state ledger interactions, is couchdb package at 'fabric/core/ledger/util/couchdb/' to be used? Or Is there a package through 'shim' interface for performing ledger operations via chaincode. Please correct my understanding on this.
And do the connectathon images on dockerhub use Couchdb?
<@U3FPBMWTA> To exploit CouchDB you would enable it with core.yaml "stateDatabase: CouchDB”, then do normal ledger interactions in chaincode with GetState() and PutState().
The underlying state database impl is transparent to the chaincode.  Under the covers it will utilize fabric/core/ledger/util/couchdb to interact with CouchDB.
CouchDB is not yet in the docker images, this is coming in the next few weeks.

The benefit of using CouchDB, is that you can then use the query system chaincode (qscc) GetQueryResult() to perform rich queries against the ledger data.  Support is also being added to query from application chaincode in the coming days.
Samples are also in the works, to make all this clear.

<@U1KFCPFQA> Is there a way to specify the endorser for transactions from a specific chaincode? e.g. I want tx from CC running on peer1 always get endorsement from peer2 and peer3, tx from CC running on peer2 always get endorsement from peer3 and peer4.
or pick consents based on where the tx is originated
in v1 the client sends to specific endorsers that it chooses, and then submits to ordering service for delivery to all peers

is it determined by this config:

committer:
        enabled: true
        ledger:
            # orderer to talk to
            orderer: 172.17.0.5:7050

I guess I am not asking the questions clearly. Just revisited the v1 architecture design doc. I think what I am looking for is a way to specify the "endorsement policies". 
In the "Next consensus architecture proposal", it says `. Every chaincode may specify an endorsement policy that may refer to a set of endorsing peers.`
<@U3U0MV3PZ> I’d suggest ask this question over on fabric-peer-dev, the folks that monitor that channel can probably describe how endorsement policy is specified

<@U1KFCPFQA>  -  regarding the couchDB discussion
1. Can we please get the scoop of couch DB API that can be called from the chaincode apart from Get/Put State? (also looking at the Indexing capability that can be explored)
2.  ` is that you can then use the query system chaincode (qscc) GetQueryResult() to perform rich queries against the ledger data `, Did you mean to say ` GetQueryResult `  API will also be available for the user chaincode?
3. Is QSCC a newly introduced system chain-code for V1.0 or this will be used by Endorsing Peer whenever there is KV world-state operation irrespective of the type of KV-ledger used?
4. Will couch-DB process be part of the Peer Image or we would be able to launch a separate docker-container dedicated for Couch-DB?
<@U3DKG7M54> I’ve clarified the v1 ledger charts to answer your questions, see charts at <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-758>.

<@U1KFCPFQA>
Can you help where do I see the value of each key using Couch DB HTTP API. I see each channel represent database name and chain-code name as a kind of namespace to each key but the value stored of the key contains revision information but not the actual value. One of the use case is to generate a separate version-dependency so endorsement doesn’t complete.

Hi, if your data is JSON it should show up in the Couch JSON response.  If your data is binary then the data is stored as a binary attachment to the JSON document in couch.  To retrieve you can call an API like <http://localhost:5984/myc1/marbles%00marble1?attachments=true>

<http://localhost:5985/rahulchannel/_all_docs>
```
where rahulhegde = chaincode name

{"total_rows":4,"offset":0,"rows":[
{"id":"lccc\u0000rahulhegde","key":"lccc\u0000rahulhegde","value":{"rev":"1-82855c8a888a9a5c566ebef25c999fff"}},
{"id":"rahulhegde\u0000a","key":"rahulhegde\u0000a","value":{"rev":"1-bb146d1e695c32ab8e4afcda86ec4839"}},
{"id":"rahulhegde\u0000b","key":"rahulhegde\u0000b","value":{"rev":"1-fa11a1c3baaadf74b7dfe9b9599b5f65"}},
{"id":"statedb_savepoint","key":"statedb_savepoint","value":{"rev":"1-3c80a37e71eeec7783ce578f500b05d1"}}
]}
```
I have run chaincode_example02 from fabric master branch which uses PutState API to store byte equivalent integer value (yes - not JSON) in couch DB.
with example02, you will see in the returned JSON that there is a binary attachment
Hello, How to set StateDB to COuchDB while starting the peer?
you’ll need to start couchdb first.  for vagrant environment, do “couchdb start”. for docker env we’ll need <@U33HN2ETU> to provide an update

Hi <@U3FPBMWTA> , here is a Docker-compse file that starts CouchDB and has the necessary environment variables+links in peer to set up couchDB properly: <https://jira.hyperledger.org/secure/attachment/10418/10418_docker-couchdb.yml>
There are three peers, but all of them basically does the same thing
